Posts.Content: jacqniel wrote: The verdict is in - and it, for the most part, is good news. The onc nurse called to say she was relaying a message from my onc (who has been out with surgery and who is now coming to the office to do paperwork, but is not seeing patients, yet). Here is the message concerning my scans: * fluid around lungs is less * there is no fluid around the heart * there is less activity in the bone * there are new spots in the lung, but are too small to measure. We will keep an eye on them. She relayed that my onc said that if the last bit of news made me nervous, he would call me. It makes me nervous, so I expect a call from him today or tomorrow. I assume the treatment will stay the same, but I will wait to see what he has to say when he calls. I have other questions that I forgot to ask the nurse - such as have the lymph glands decreased in size, etc. The wait is over. The verdict is in. I am happy for the most part, yet a bit concerned. I will just put it in God's hands. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: jacqniel wrote: Hi all my dear sisters, I am writing this to let you know I am going to be taking a break from the boards for awhile.  My health has been deteriorating the last few weeks and I just don't have the energy for it.  My liver enzymes have quadrupled in the last three weeks so this is probably what is causing my problems.  I will start a new chemo combo on Monday and am praying it kicks my new liver mets to the curb and continues to keep the rest stable (at best).  My symptoms - which have been slowly progressing are: lack of appetite, frequent bowel  movements (not diarrhea), gassy, nausea, pain under right rib (but all tests say it is not the liver capsule or pancreas), pain under my left rib (ultra sound showed the spleen was enlarged), random soreness in belly, weakness, hot flashes, achy muscles.  I am so tired of this!  Just a week and a half ago I went out to lunch, went shopping and had a facial.  The next day everything began to change.  I can still drive to go through a drive-thru - like a bank or Walgreens, but the thought of walking around a grocery store almost frightens me - I don't think I would have the strength! Has anyone else had this with liver mets?  I am praying it is reversible!  My new tx is Carboplatin and Gemzar. Some good news is my liver is still functioning in the normal range and my heart is looking hail and hearty.  I am very thankful for that! I will check back to see if anyone has any words of wisdom, but I know how I worry about all of you when you haven't posted for awhile.  Hugs to you all, Jacque Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Ill jacqniel ozzie2

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2007 05:27PM jacqniel wrote: Ok, I posted a response this morning, and I swear I saw it and that it went to the top of the list of threads.  I guess I am going to have to claim chemo brain? Just wanted to let you know that I seem to be responding to the new tx and my liver enzymes have already dropped 200 points each in a week's time.  Quite encouraging.  I still have no energy and my onc says I just need to be patient - there isn't a quick fix.  Sigh. Patience has never been one of my virtues.  I had new tx number two today.  I am hoping my SEs won't be as nasty as last week's. Thanks for all your kind words and encouragement, dear sisters.  You are appreciated. Hugs, Jacque
Posts.Title: Ill jacqniel ozzie2

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2007 05:10AM jacqniel wrote: Just a quick note to let you know I am alive and kicking - just not kicking as hard as normal.  My liver enzymes have been critically inflated and I have been reaping the 'rewards' - bloated, fluid in the belly, nausea, listless.  I ended up in the hosptial for three days while they tried to give me some relief.  I do think I am relatively better, but I am certainly not where I want to be.  I have my second installment of chemo today (had first of Carbo/Gemzar last Monday and Carbo/Aredia today).  Come on chemo - knock this crud to the moon! Thanks everyone for all your kind words.  They mean the world to me.  I hate not coming on the boards regularly - but I just don't have the energy right now.  Please know I am thinking about you all send healing prayers to you. Hugs and love, Jacque

Posts.Content: jacqniel wrote: Well, I have already heard from my oncs office.  You gotta love that man!  He is going to start me on Carboplatin and Gemzar.  If I understood him correctly, he will do both txs on the first day.  Repeat Gemzar (I think) on day eight and then give me a week off.  Does this sound right?  Has anyone else been on this combo?  If so, what were the side effects?  I know this is the least of my worries, but is my hair going to come back or still be absent?  I couldn't tell from what I could find on the internet. I asked about doing a biopsy, and he said from an oncologist's standpoint, it wouldn't change his tx.  BUT if I wanted one, he would schedule it.  I am torn.  What do you think? I also asked about RFA and he said I had too many lesions to be effective.  No one has told me how many, just 'multiple' but they are tiny.  Does this sound right?  Thank you dear sisters.  I do so appreciate your input.  Hugs, Jacque Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: jacqniel wrote: Hi Deb! Sometimes it is better to start a new thread if you have specific questions rather than tagging on someone elses post. I am sorry I missed your question the other day, but here is my answer to your questions about avastin. I have had six TXs of Avastin three weeks apart. It is a fairly easy tx compared to many. It causes membranes to dry out, so nose bleeds, bleeding gums and bowel bleeding are common. It also can cause your blood pressure to increase. I am on BP meds, and while it does get higher for the first week after tx, it hasn't caused any problems and returns to normal the second week after tx. I am also on Abraxane, so I think my other SEs are related to it. I sure hope this helps - and I hope you hang in there with us. After all - we are in this together! Hugs, Jacque Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2007 12:25PM jacqniel wrote: Mary Jo, It is very doubtful that you are experiencing pain from bone mets.  It is most likely the Neulasta - and maybe even the tx.  Neulasta is a wonderful terrible drug.  It keeps our white cells in the normal range while wreaking havoc on our bodies.  Some hints for you are: Have the nurse give you the shot in your stomach - you will have less shoulder and neck pain.  Start taking an extra strength pain reliever before you get the pain and keep using for four or five days around the clock.  I use Arthritis Tylenol. Take a benedryl before you get the shot (or right when you get home - remember they can make your sleepy). Remember, too, the first couple of shots are usually the worse and the SEs will settle down (a bit) as time goes on.  Hang in there! Oh, and a good rule of thumb is, if the pain persists for more than two weeks, have it checked out.  Better to error on the side of caution.

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2007 07:51AM jacqniel wrote: The first time I was dx with bc I, too, lost my eyelashes a month or so after my last tx - and then again, and again! On one thread a while ago someone explained that the reason your eyelashes fall out more than one time has to do with the life cycle of the eyelash. Under normal circumstances our eyelashes fall out at different times and then regrow and but the others mask that they are gone. When we lose our lashes all at once, all the lashes are on the same cycle for awhile, so all drop at the same time. It may take a few cycles to get them to not all drop at the same time. Hope this helps explain it! Jacque

Wendy is right, stay away from statistics - YOU are not a statistic.  Plus, most of the information you see is so outdated - always check the year published - bc treatments have grown in leaps and bounds. I was dx with mets last Dec in my bones and lungs.  Just this Monday I found out it is now in my liver.  What has given me peace this week is knowing there are many women on this board with liver mets - and living with it.  Prayers that your onc will find the winning combination to knock this beast out of your body and for peace and comfort as you begin this new journey in your life. Hugs, Jacque

Posts.Title: Question on bone mets marina05 jacqniel

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2007 08:49AM jacqniel wrote: I had my last Abraxane dose in the series of three yesterday.  My white blood cells were low, so I have to go in for a Neulasta shot today.  One of the reasons I decided to switch to the weekly regime was because I thought I could avoid the Neulasta shot - it does a number on me.  So, I think I am going to go back to one tx every three weeks.  Then I just have to experience the constipation once, body aches once, etc., and then have two decent weeks.  I will be down and out for a few days, but that is better than feeling that way most of the time.  We'll see.  Maybe after the going back to DD I will decide the other way is better.  My problem is, I don't really want to do either! I get to have a little chemo break, too!  We are going to the Elton John concert the weekend after I was suppose to have my next chemo.  My onc said he wanted to see me up dancing and enjoying myself (he is going to the concert, too) so he moved my tx to the next week.  Yea!  Now, if my scans just cooperate next week and show that my tx is working, I'll be set!  B445 - so sorry about your port - that stinks!  My first port, four years ago was horrible the whole year I had it.  It always hurt, would never draw blood - I hated it.  My present port is great - no pain, I forget it is there, draws like a dream.  Prayers for an excellent one this time! Topo - So glad you are getting a good response!  Keep kicking that beasts hinney!

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2007 01:16PM jacqniel wrote: Ok, I tried to post to this thread about six times this morning and it wouldn't let me.  Hopefully it will go through now! Congratulations on the good scans! I had been doing dose dense infusions of Abraxane and Avastin the last six months, but changed to weekly this week due to side effects.  So far, it has been much easier on me - hope that keeps up! I had a scan in June which showed some areas of improvement and some areas stable.  I am due for another scan on the 24th of this month.  I am a little apprehensive as my TMs have risen some and some other numbers have increased on lab work.  Like all of us, I SO want this to work - and I SO want to get a nice long dance with NED.  How have your side effects been? Posts.Title: Abraxane and Avastin combo weekly b445 mgk63

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2007 07:13PM jacqniel wrote: I have been on A/A since March of this year.  I was on the three week cycle, switched this last round to weekly for three weeks with one week off - and will switch back to every three weeks the next round (if my scans today are good).  My SEs sound similar to everyone else's.  Neuropathy, leg weakness, bladder issues, skin issues on hands, nail problems, dry eye syndrome, little scabs all over my body, bloody nose, bloody stools, excessive nasal drainage, etc.   I use to get an acne like condition on my face, but that seems to have stopped, and of course - fatique.
